subject: Negotiation
title: Business Card Rituals
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Business Card Rituals.

hook.text: In Japan, a business card is an extension of your identity. Stuffing it in your pocket is an insult.

buildup.text: Japanese meishi exchange involves presenting cards with both hands, reading them carefully, and placing them respectfully.

discovery.text: Writing on someone's card in front of them â€” common in the West â€” is deeply disrespectful in Japan.

twist.text: Digital contact sharing hasn't replaced cards in most Asian cultures. The ritual carries meaning beyond information.

climax.text: Carry cards when traveling internationally. Present them respectfully. It costs nothing and signals everything.

punchline.text: A small card can make a big first impression â€” for better or worse.

quiz.question: Why are business cards still important in Japanese culture?
options: The exchange ritual carries meaning about respect and identity
Email hasn't been adopted in Japan
